Xerox Corp. on Thursday reported higher fourth-quarter profits from continuing operations, buoyed by strong demand for its document management solutions and a successful expansion into emerging markets. The Stamford, Connecticut-based company posted net income of $180 million, or 15 cents per share, compared to $160 million, or 13 cents per share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue for the quarter climbed to $5.2 billion, up from $5.0 billion a year ago.

"These results underscore the effectiveness of our strategic initiatives and the resilience of our business model," said Ursula Burns, Xerox's CEO. "Our focus on innovation, customer satisfaction, and operational efficiency continues to pay dividends."

Key drivers of the growth included a surge in sales of multifunction printers and an increase in service contracts, particularly in Asia and Latin America. The company's digital transformation services, which help organizations transition from paper-based processes to digital workflows, also saw substantial uptake.
